awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:   Software platform to predict patient no-shows using machine learning algorithms
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of an AI-based healthcare patient scheduling system.  Patient no-shows to medical appointments are a major logistical and economic challenge for clinics and hospitals, with an estimated average yearly no-show rate for primary care/specialty medical appointments of 20 - 35% leading to significant revenue loss.  In addition, patients who failed to keep an appointment were 70% more likely not to return within 18 months, and older patients experiencing chronic illnesses are likely not to return to their physicians’ offices after missing just one appointment.  Missing an appointment has been shown to create a significant negative impact on disease management leading to increased morbidity and increased costs. Factors that cause patients to miss their appointments have been identified, and the proposed system offers a proactive solution that may result in higher appointment adherence.  Reduced missed appointments may decrease economic costs in medical services such as imaging studies, and downstream services resulting such as pharmacy services and medical equipment services. The proposed technology may increase operational efficiency by minimizing empty timeslots, increasing revenue, and also may lead to a significant boost in patient and clinician satisfaction and improved patient outcomes.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of software tool that employs AI-based predictive models that has the potential to more accurately predict patient no-show and cancellation rates.  Initial testing of the proposed AI-based algorithm resulted in no-show prediction rates of up to 90% as compared to other software applications using least-squares predictive techniques, which realized a 68% prediction rate. In addition, the use of a patient’s historical demographic data allows the system to learn/improve, increasing prediction accuracy over time. Currently available solutions are not dynamically adaptive and are dependent on individual physicians for protocols, which increases variability in scheduling and hence difficult to implement at a system level. The proposed algorithm provides the likelihood of appointment adherence based on patient’s historic behavior, and clinics and hospitals as well as patients may benefit by scheduling appointments more efficiently.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Technology description

Aspiration LLC has developed an automated AI-based machine learning algorithm effective at reducing the impact of no-show rates by 5-10% for outpatient clinic physicians, ambulatory administrators, and clinic schedulers by providing insights for effectively scheduling appointments, which can improve quality of care and patient disease management. The software tool developed by our team employs AI-based predictive models and has the potential to more accurately predict patient no-show rates than other modeling solutions, decreasing lost revenue within hospital-based clinics and clinical enterprises attributed to no-shows. Further, the algorithm uses patient’s historical demographic data to learn/improve, increasing prediction accuracy overtime. Currently available solutions are not dynamically adaptive, are dependent on individual physicians for protocols which increases variability in scheduling, and are, therefore, difficult to implement at a system level. 

Commercial opportunities:

We believe, based on the knowledge gained from customer interviews, that ambulatory clinic leaders, including administrators, physicians, and clinic schedulers in medical enterprises, will be interested in our technology since it can significantly boost patient and clinician satisfaction by optimizing patient care and revenue generation. We have tested the algorithm on multiple longitudinal data sets and have noted it to be a dynamic model that adapts and improves over time. Our algorithm provides the likelihood of appointment adherence dynamically based on a patient’s historic behavior together with additional features. Scheduling departments of hospital-based clinics and large clinical enterprises will benefit by scheduling patients more efficiently on any given clinic day; with more efficient scheduling increasing revenue generation and maximizing patient care.

 

Broader Impacts

Patient no-shows to medical appointments are a major logistical/economic challenge for clinics/hospitals, with an estimated average yearly no-show rate of 20% for both primary care and specialty medical appointments, leading to significant revenue losses (e.g., more than $150 billion/year in the US ). Additionally, patients who failed to keep an appointment were 70% more likely not to return within 18 months, with older patients experiencing more chronic illnesses and being more likely not to return to their physicians’ offices after missing just one appointment. Our platform directly benefits both the medical provider and promotes better outcomes at the individual level. Additionally, the predictive power of the technology that we highlight in the pediatric population can also be expanded to other medical departments and specialties in the future. This is possible due to the innate scalability of the software platform that allows for inclusion of additional data components, such as qualitative factors of patient care, laboratory values, or data obtained from procedural-based modalities. By better predicting the incidence of patient no-shows, the prototype offers a solution for minimizing wasted medical expenditures, maximizing efficient patient care, and identifying the socio/economic factors responsible for missed appointments

Lessons learned during NSF course from our 104 customer interviews

• Reached out practice administrators and operational leads in clinics as we learned that they ar the real decision makers

• Learned from the clinic leaders / administrators on where they get information regarding practice changes

• Reached out to Dental and Veterinary practices as possible customers.

Learned that small practices might be our first customers.

• Realized that call center and nurses are not our customers

 

Key Outcomes:

  • Path Forward 2.  Launch Startup (soft money) an e-Health company called Aspirations, LLC and applying for an SBIR grant.  “Intends to build a business and will have employees within 12 months as further work is done to validate the business model and reduce technical risk)
  • Continue to interview people in our segments and discover answers to these questions:
    • Where do they get information regarding practice changes?
    • When was the last time a practice change was made?
    • Who really is the decision maker?

 


Last Modified: 07/14/2022
Modified by: Janani K Narumanchi
